sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in adults or geriatric patients

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• safety and efficacy not established in patients 1 year of age and older
  • Infant botulism, Caused by toxin type A or B: less than 1 year of age, 1.5 mL/kg (75 mg/kg) IV as soon as diagnosis is made; start infusion at 0.5 mL/kg/hr (25 mg/kg/hr) and may increase to 1 mL/kg/hr (50 mg/kg/hr) after 15 min if no untoward reactions occur; do not exceed a rate of 1 mL/kg/hr

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: renal insufficiency, any degree of or at risk of: administer at the minimum concentration and minimum rate of infusion; do not exceed recommended dose

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Infant botulism, Caused by toxin type A or B

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• selective IgA deficiency
  • severe reaction to other human immunoglobulin preparations

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• concomitant use with nephrotoxic drugs; increased risk of acute renal failure; monitoring recommended
  • diabetes mellitus; increased risk of acute renal failure; monitoring recommended
  • live virus vaccine use not recommended within 5 months after botulism immune globulin administration
  • paraproteinemia; increased risk of acute renal failure; monitoring recommended
  • renal insufficiency; increased risk of acute renal failure; monitoring recommended
  • sepsis; increased risk of acute renal failure; monitoring recommended
  • volume depletion; increased risk of acute renal failure; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension (2%)
  • Dermatologic:Erythematous condition (up to 14%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hyponatremia (5%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia (5%)
  • Otic:Otitis media (11%)
  • Renal:Urinary tract infectious disease (2%)
  • Respiratory:Pneumonia (11%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Hypotension
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Aseptic meningitis
  • Respiratory:Respiratory arrest (2%)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • reconstitute single-dose vial with 2 mL Sterile Water for Injection, USP
  • infusion should begin within 2 hours after reconstitution is complete and should be concluded within 4 hours of reconstitution
  • administer through a separate IV line; if not possible, infuse through a separate line containing Sodium Chloride and/or Dextrose in Water 2.5% to 20%; use of an in-line or syringe-tip 18 micrometer filter is recommended
  • pre-dilution not recommended; if required, dilute no more than 1:2 with sodium chloride and/or dextrose solutions
  • start infusion at 0.5 mL/kg/hr (25 mg/kg/hr); if well-tolerated after 15 minutes, may increase to 1 mL/kg/hr (50 mg/kg/hr)
  • do not exceed administration rate of 1 mL/kg/hr (50 mg/kg/hr)
  • slow or temporarily interrupt infusion for minor adverse reactions; discontinue infusion and administer epinephrine for anaphylaxis or hypotension.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• renal function tests and urinary output prior to administration
  • renal function tests during administration in patients at risk for acute renal failure
  • monitor for hypotension, anaphylaxis, or other allergic symptoms

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise caregiver or parent to avoid vaccination of the child for at least 5 months after treatment.
  • This drug may cause erythema, hypotension, anemia, otitis media, or pneumonia.
